content: Do we actually need Join Stream button as well as Subscribe, Add or Configure stream buttons in left side bar? I have personally never used the Join Stream button and used to think till a point that it was for creating a new stream. (We also reuse the + symbol for creating new stream once we are inside the stream management window). Maybe we can just remove the Join Stream button from left sidebar so that the user has one less button to figure out what it does?
I don't have a strong opinion, but I'll give the data point that I almost never use it.
I almost never use the + button.
I only use the + button, and have never used the gear button, which I think is a data point in support of this (that there only needs to be 1 button).

I tend to use the Join Stream (+) button instead of the Subscribe, Add or Configure streams button, and for a long time thought the gear icon was some sort of "display settings for streams" or otherwise a configuration button, and I was surprised when I learned I could add/join streams from the gear menu.
I agree that the gear cog is kind of misleading
I think it could make sense to collapse the +/gear buttons into one thing that's a direct link to the "All streams" view

On a slightly related note, it's sort of odd that the search bar for streams is closed by default, and the one for the buddy list is open by default. My vote would be to have the left sidebar search bar be always open. The screen real estate is valuable, but saving one line only puts off the inevitable need to search or scroll.
I'm skeptical of having it always open more because it could add to a feeling of clutter than because of the space.
I was telling people to use the + button today to add themselves to a stream, but I would be supportive of merging the + and gear buttons, which seem to do the same thing (?).

Note that some people may only have a short list of streams, in which case Tim's point about clutter is well-taken. Though I guess it's also possible for all the users in an organization to also fit in one screen.

The downward arrow is misleading as it signifies expansion and collapse of stream topics, rather when we click on it, we are presented with stream options, a three dot menu might be more apt for this., and we can use the arrow to collapse and expand the topics.

Just want to clarify Siddharth, the space on the left side with the stream names is typically called the left sidebar or the stream list and the one on the right with user names is typically called the buddy list or the right sidebar. Most people here would probably describe "narrow" as the list of messages in center or as the "filter" that defines which list of messages are being shown, so eg #design takes you to the design stream narrow.

strange... I'm sure the concept of "narrow" was well explained in one of the doc pages but I can't seem to find a link to share here... maybe it was just a message on czo instead.

@Siddharth I think the "down arrow" should be used only when a list of sub-options needs to be displayed. It also tells about a priority order i.e. first this (say stream name in left sidebar or icon for message actions in narrow) needs to be displayed then the underlying options. Incase for "right arrow", it should be used when it leads to a fresh content i.e. in the narrow irrespective of the position where it is getting displayed (left or right) wrt itself. I propose the right arrow can be used in right sidebar over a user name when hovered. Worth experimenting I feel. Also @Yash RE thanks for clarification!!
